definition: he or him/(used for either sex when the sex is unknown or unimportant)/(used before sb's name for emphasis)/(used as a meaningless mock object)/other/another

(after a verb or adjective) one who (is) .../(after a noun) person involved in .../-er/-ist/(used after a number or 後|后[hou4] or 前[qian2] to refer to sth mentioned previously)/(used after a term, to mark a pause before defining the term)/(old) (used at the end of a command)/(old) this

sentences.english: We must also discover "others" and the intersubjective world.
sentences.chinese: 我们必须发现“他者”和主体间性的世界。

sentences.english: Merlin was also a zero-level Other, as was Jesus).
sentences.chinese: 梅林也是一个零度他者，跟耶稣一样。
是吧？你在使他者工具化。

sentences.english: God enfolds, without otherness, all things.
sentences.chinese: 神不借助任何他者而包容一切。

sentences.english: The appearance of Xuelai in Wu Mi's poetry is an image he carefully constructs.
sentences.chinese: 吴宓诗歌中的雪莱形象是他精心构建的他者形象。
而他者只等待咸湿的遗忘。

sentences.english: Lacan Shit is the languaged Other.
Over the last few days, they've opened up their homes to one another.
sentences.chinese: 在过去的这些日子里，他们已经向他者开放了住宅。

sentences.english: The others' existence is an objective reality.
sentences.chinese: 他者的存在，是一种客观实在。

sentences.english: The retreat of the accepted Big Other accounts for the prevalence of code-cracking in popular culture.
sentences.chinese: 公认大他者的退却解释了流行文化中破解密文的盛行。

sentences.english: So it was the "Other" in Christian culture.
sentences.chinese: 这样，景教在西方基督教文化中就成了一个“他者”。

sentences.english: Other" is an indispensable term in post-modem translation theory."
sentences.chinese: “他者”是后现代翻译理论中一个不可或缺的术语。

sentences.english: This truth can be seen most vividly in our interactions with other people.
sentences.chinese: 这一事实最能生动地表现在我们与他者的交往中。

sentences.english: To be enslaved is to be owned as property by another.
sentences.chinese: 被奴役，就是被他者像拥有财产那样被拥有。

sentences.english: Only zero-level Others may get to the seventh level of the Twilight.
sentences.chinese: 只有零度他者可以到达黄昏界的第七层。

definition: inner transcendence (perfection through one's own inner moral cultivation, as in Confucianism, for example)
dualism, belief that the universe is made of two different substance (e.g. mind and matter or good and evil)
